fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Categories for the Working Mathematician provides an array of general ideas useful in a wide variety of fields. Starting from the foundations, this book illuminates the concepts of category, functor, natural transformation, and duality. The book then turns to adjoint functors, which provide a description of universal constructions, an analysis of the representations of functors by sets of morphisms, and a means of manipulating direct and inverse limits. These categorical concepts are extensively illustrated in the remaining chapters, which include many applications of the basic existence theorem for adjoint functors. The categories of algebraic systems are constructed from certain adjoint-like data and characterized by Beck's theorem. After considering a variety of applications, the book continues with the construction and exploitation of Kan extensions. This second edition includes a number of revisions and additions, including two new chapters on topics of active interest. One is onsymmetric monoidal categories and braided monoidal categories and the coherence theorems for them. The second describes 2-categories and the higher dimensional categories which have recently come into prominence. The bibliography has also been expanded to cover some of the many other recent advances concerning categories.
A subobject is normal if it is the kernel of some map.
A subgroup is a subobject in Grp, written H\leq G; equivalently, it is a subset closed under the group operations.

fr:title.text: The subobjects of a presheaf form a Heyting algebra

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The subobjects of a presheaf form a Heyting algebra

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let C^\text {op}\xrightarrow {P} Set be a presheaf. Then the subobject poset of P is a Heyting algebra.

A subfunctor of a [functor] C\xrightarrow {F} D is merely a subobject in the functor category D^C; this is computed pointwise, so that a subfunctor consists of a functor C\xrightarrow {G} D such that Gc\hookrightarrow Fc for each c\in C, naturally in C.

Let \hat {C} be a presheaf category. Let C^\text {op}\xrightarrow {\Omega } Set be the sieve functor, which sends an object x to the set of sieves on x, and a map y\xrightarrow {f}x to its action on sieves by restriction: (\Omega f)(S) = \{g: fg\in S\}. Let *\xhookrightarrow {\top } \Omega (where * is the constant functor at the singleton) identify for each x\in C the maximal sieve. Then \top is a subobject classifier in \hat {C}.

Let Q\hookrightarrow P be a subobject in \hat {C}. We need to define the classifying natural transformation P\xrightarrow {\chi _Q}\Omega ; we work in components. At an object x\in C, this map must send an element p\in Px to a sieve on x; we choose the sieve (\chi _Q)_x(p) = \{z\xrightarrow {f} x\in C: p|_f \in Qz\}. In other words, this sieve consists of those maps which restrict p to an element of Q.

Next, to show that it is a pullback, it suffices to show that it is a pullback at each x\in C, and by the construction of limits in Set, it suffices to show that (\chi _Q)_x(p) is the maximal sieve if and only if p\in Qx. The backwards direction is already done; conversely, if it is the maximal sieve, then we obtain the result by observing that 1_x\in (\chi _Q)_x(p) and applying the definition of \chi _Q.

Finally, to show uniqueness, suppose that we have another natural transformation P\xrightarrow {\theta } \Omega . By the above argument, for the square to be a pullback, we must have that \theta _x(p) is the maximal sieve if and only if p\in Qx. Now further, given z\xrightarrow {f} x and applying the same fact at z, we must have that p|_f\in Qz if and only if \theta _z(p|_f) is the maximal sieve. By naturality of \theta at a map f, we have that \theta _z(p|_f) = \Omega f(\theta _x(p)), which by definition of \Omega is the maximal sieve if and only if f\in \theta _x(p). As a consequence, if the square is a pullback, we must have that f\in \theta _x(p) if and only if p|_f\in Qz, yielding exactly the definition of \chi _Q above.
A category C is well-powered if all its subobject posets are small.
A subset is a subobject in Set. Notationally, it is specified as \{x\in X: \phi (x)\}, where \phi (x) is the classifying map of the subobject.

Let D\xrightarrow {G} C be a continuous functor with complete domain and locally small domain and codomain. Suppose that D has a small coseparating family and that every collection of subobjects x_\alpha \hookrightarrow x in D admits a meet, i.e. a limit. Then G has a left adjoint.

A subcategory of a category C is a collection of objects and morphisms from C closed under composition and containing all the identities. Following the pattern of subobjects, we identify a subcategory with the inclusion [functor] into C; in this sense, a subcategory is a faithful and injective on objects functor.

A preorder is a category P in which, for each pair of objects x and y, P(x, y) is either empty or a singleton. Explicitly, this means that it has a collection of elements (its objects) and a reflexive, transitive relation (inhabitance of hom-sets).
A morphism x\xhookrightarrow {f} y is a monomorphism if for any pair of parallel arrows z\overset {g,h}{\rightrightarrows } x, fg = fh implies g = h.
A category C consists of the following data:

fr:ul.fr:li: a collection of objects, overloadingly also called C;
for each pair of objects x,y\in C, a collection of morphisms C(x, y);
for each object x\in C, a designated identity morphism x\xrightarrow {1_x} x;
for each pair of morphisms x\xrightarrow {f} y\xrightarrow {g} z, a designated composite morphism x\xrightarrow {gf} z.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This data must satisfy the following axioms:

fr:ul.fr:li: unitality: for any x\xrightarrow {f} y, 1_yf = f = f1_x;
associativity: for any x\xrightarrow {f} y\xrightarrow {g}z\xrightarrow {h}w, h(gf) = (hg)f.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In other words, the following diagrams must commute:
A poset is a preorder which is skeletal as a category; equivalently, this means its relation is additionally antisymmetric.
